A: The problem is that you are not separating the two strings you are sending. When you call `outputStream.write(username.getText().getBytes());` and `outputStream.write(password.getText().getBytes());`, you are writing the bytes of both strings to the output stream without any delimiter. This means that when you read the input stream on the server side, you are reading the entire content of the input stream as a single string, which explains why you are getting "usernamepassword" as your output.

To solve this, you need to add a delimiter between the two strings. This delimiter can be any character or sequence of characters that you know will not appear in your actual data. For example, you could use a special character like "|" or a specific string like "END_OF_USERNAME". Then, on the server side, you would read the input stream until you encounter this delimiter, and then continue reading the rest of the input stream as the password.

Here is an example of how you could modify your code:

Client.java:
```java
outputStream.write(username.getText().getBytes());
outputStream.write("|".getBytes()); // Add a delimiter
outputStream.write(password.getText().getBytes());
```

Server.java:
```java
byte[] username = new byte[20];
int bytesRead = inputStream.read(username);
String user = new String(username, 0, bytesRead);

// Find the delimiter
int delimiterIndex = user.indexOf("|");

// If the delimiter is found, split the string
if (delimiterIndex != -1) {
    String usr = user.substring(0, delimiterIndex);
    String pass = user.substring(delimiterIndex + 1);
    System.out.println("username = " + usr);
    System.out.println("password = " + pass);
} else {
    System.out.println("No delimiter found");
}
```

In this example, the delimiter "|" is used to separate the username and password. You can replace it with any character or sequence of characters that you know will not appear in your actual data.
